items.title: Treachery and stupidity to the fore as Robert Jenrick defects to Reform | John Crace
items.content_html:
Even Nigel Farage looked taken aback by the news Honest Bob was about to join his flock, but he quickly saw the upside

  • UK politics live ‚Äì latest updates

One is too many and a thousand never enough. Addiction is a tricky business. What starts as fun inevitably, insidiously tears away the soul. And there are signs that Nigel Farage‚Äôs press conference habit is getting badly out of control. He started off at one a week. Then that no longer worked. His narcissistic need craved more and more attention. So he upped it to two or three a week. Each time the buzz got less. He was mainlining more and more just to try and stand still. To keep the withdrawals at bay. Still not enough. So on Thursday, Nige upped the dose to two inside a day. This can only end in a spell in rehab. Followed by meetings of PA. Pressers Anonymous.

Boom. The best laid plans etc. Nige was just six minutes into his first press conference of the day ‚Äì the unveiling of the latest Tory defector, the meg-rich Malcolm Offord, whose lifetime achievements amount to buying yachts, as the leader or Reform Scotland ‚Äì when it all kicked off. Malc had just signed a card renouncing his peerage, when every journalist in the room started looking at their phones. There was breaking news. Kemi Badenoch had just announced she was sacking Robert Jenrick from the shadow cabinet and the Tory party.

Continue reading...

items.content_html:
Former shadow justice secretary turns fire on Tories and Labour as he joins Nigel Farage‚Äôs party

  • Full report: Badenoch sacks Jenrick

Nigel Farage, speaking at his press conference in Scotland, has said that ‚Äúof course‚Äù he has had conversations with Robert Jenrick, who was sacked by Kemi Badenoch this morning for planning to defect.

UPDATE: Farage said:

I have had conversations with a number of very senior conservatives over the course of the last week, the last month. A lot of them realise that for all the talk on 8 May the Conservative Party will cease to be a national party. They will be obliterated in Scotland, Wales, the red wall councils.

As far as Mr Jenrick is concerned, of course I have talked to Robert Jenrick. Was I on the verge of signing him up? No. But we have had conversations.

This morning I removed the Conservative whip from Robert Jenrick after dismissing him from the shadow cabinet.

I was very sorry to be presented with clear, irrefutable evidence, not just that he was preparing to defect, but he was planning to so in the most damaging way to the Conservative party and shadow cabinet colleagues.

There are a few reasons that Donald Trump ‚Äì now self-anointed acting president of Venezuela, as well as the United States ‚Äì might be so excited about appropriating Venezuela‚Äôs oil.

items.title: How ‚Äòday zero‚Äô water shortages in Iran are fuelling protests
items.content_html:
Supply failures are dramatic example of way climate crisis threatens basic human needs ‚Äì and with it political stability

  • Iran protests ‚Äì live updates

Gripped by a terrible drought now entering its sixth year, Iran‚Äôs cities are on the brink of what its meteorological organisation calls ‚Äúwater day zero‚Äù: the boundary beyond which supply systems no longer function. This was crossed by Chennai in India in summer 2019 and is now threatening Mashhad, Tabriz and Tehran, where taps in the city‚Äôs southern districts had already run dry by early December.

Nightly ‚Äúpressure cuts‚Äù, in which the water supply is halted to whole districts in the capital, have become the norm. Protesters demanding ‚ÄúWater, electricity, life ‚Äì our basic right‚Äù over the summer were already risking a clampdown.

items.title: Iranian airspace reopens ‚Äì as it happened
items.content_html:
US president says ‚Äòimportant sources‚Äô told him executions are not going ahead. This live blog is now closed ‚Äì our new blog is here

For the first time in days, Iranians were able to make calls abroad from their mobiles on Tuesday, according to reporting by Associated Press. Texting services have not been restored, however, and nor has the internet.

Although Iranians were able to call abroad, they could not receive calls from outside the country, several people in the capital told Associated Press. The internet remained blocked, they said, though it is possible to access some government-approved websites.

Cloudfare - an internet infrastructure provider, and one of several companies and monitors tracking the status of internet traffic in Iran ‚Äì said traffic volumes have remained ‚Äúat a fraction of a percent of previous levels‚Äù. Its latest update as of 01:00 UTC (which is about three hours and 30 minutes ago), shows a continued widespread blackout. Iran has been under an internet shutdown since Thursday night.

Brief windows of connectivity were observed on Friday, but these did not last, according to Cloudfare.

Netblocks, an independent global internet monitor, also notes that while some phone calls from Iran are connecting, there is ‚Äúno secure way to communicate‚Äù and the general public remain cut off from the outside world.
